overview.short: Vibrio cholerae is a Gram-negative, motile curved rod that can cause cholera and gastroenteritis; it is notable for being less salt-dependent than many marine Vibrios.
overview.clinical_context: Classically associated with profuse watery diarrhea (cholera) and can also cause sporadic gastroenteritis; exposure is typically via contaminated water or food.

species_markers.notes: Unlike many halophilic Vibrios, V. cholerae does not require high salt and typically does not tolerate 6.5% NaCl.
Typically yields yellow colonies on TCBS Agar due to sucrose fermentation.
Supports differentiation from some other Vibrio species in biochemical panels.

common_confusions.reason: Both may be sucrose-positive on TCBS; salt tolerance helps separate them.
Overlap in oxidase positivity and general Vibrio phenotype; clinical context differs.

when_to_question_identification: Strong growth at 6.5% NaCl argues against V. cholerae and supports halophilic Vibrios.
Oxidase negativity is inconsistent with Vibrio.
Failure to ferment sucrose on TCBS should prompt consideration of non-sucrose fermenting Vibrios.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Determines toxigenic potential and outbreak relevance (e.g., O1/O139).
recommended_next_tests.api_kit: PCR panel (cholera toxin / ctx genes) or latex agglutination serogrouping kit
